posts.name: Landon
posts.cooked: What motor encoders would you recommend to use that have low cost and reliable for counting the rotations that a motor makes rotating an arm that moves game pieces?

posts.name: Christian Femia
posts.cooked:
You have a bunch of options for motor encoders:

Brushless motor controllers ( SparkMAX , TalonFX ), have encoders built in - but their position isn’t saved after a power cycle

CANCoders can be used to read the absolute position of a mechanism (edit: within one full rotation) - which will also be saved after a power cycle

SRX Mag Encoders also read the absolute position, similar to a CANCoder, but needs to interface through a motor controller, not over CAN

Rev Through Bore encoder can be placed wherever you’d like the measure the rotation output as well - but also needs to interface through a motor controller

All encoders are great options, all with their own trade-offs and benefits. I’m personally a big fan of SparkMAXs and CANCoders, they have been able to do all the tasks I need them for, and they just work.

link_counts.title: SPARK MAX Motor Controller - REV Robotics
Falcon 500 Powered by Talon FX - CTR Electronics

posts.name: Landon
posts.cooked: Do you have example code for pulling the position from the spark max using a neo motor or rev hex motor encoder?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
ChristianFemia:

absolute position of a mechanism - which will also be saved after a power cycle

Generally that isn’t true although it may be OP’s case. Only the position of one revolution of the motor is known so that restricts knowing the position of a mechanism to only if the range of the mechanism is one revolution or less of the motor.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: All of the options @ChristianFemia gave are great. We used this 10-turn potentiometer last year on our turret. It works well if you need the absolute position beyond a single turn.

posts.name: Christian Femia
posts.cooked:
Rev has some amazing code examples on their GitHub ( Java / C++ ). What you are probably looking for is either:

Read Encoder Values ( Java / C++ )

Alternate Encoder ( Java / C++ )

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: FWIW, you can also connect PWM encoders (REV Though Bore, SRX MAG, etc.) directly to the roboRIO.  Same goes for analog ones.  This covers most common absolute encoders in the FRC ecosystem.  Be sure you can mechanically interface to whatever you pick!
